meaning_mnemonic:
外れる is "to come off" or "to be off." And this is its noun form — <vocabulary>a miss</vocabulary>, aka something that's <vocabulary>off the mark</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, it's completely off the original goal or intended target.

This word refers to something that falls outside of what's expected, central, or correct. Like something that didn't match your hopes or expectations — a losing lottery ticket or a disappointing purchase. It can also describe a place on the <vocabulary>periphery</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>outskirts</vocabulary> — since you're "off the mark" from somewhere more central.

The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>world</kanji> is the <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it <vocabulary>the world</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary> for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.

感心 expresses that you are <vocabulary>being impressed</vocabulary> by someone's effort, skill, or good behavior. You'll hear it when someone does something <vocabulary>praiseworthy</vocabulary> and you genuinely admire it, like 感心した (I’m impressed).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pray</kanji> and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to pray for</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>pray</kanji> and make a <kanji>request</kanji>, as a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary> to some deity at a shrine or temple. 

This usually refers to making a wish or asking for a favor from a deity, like prosperity, good health, or winning an important sports game.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give birth</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to give birth</vocabulary>.

You know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know.
A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>flute</kanji>... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By <vocabulary>whistling</vocabulary>.
You know how 参加 is <kanji>participation</kanji>? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary>.
You know that 参加 is <kanji>participation</kanji>, so <kanji>someone</kanji> who does participation is a <vocabulary>participant</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>police</kanji> (警察) <kanji>government</kanji> is full of <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>s. This is the formal way to say "police officer." It is similar to 警官, but has a slightly more official feel to it.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Throw Something Out Of Order

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going <vocabulary>to put in disorder</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to throw out of order</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disturb</vocabulary> whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for your actions.
You know how 宇宙 is <kanji>space</kanji>? Well, a <kanji>person</kanji> from space is an <vocabulary>alien</vocabulary>.

You know how 宇宙 is <kanji>outer space</kanji> and how 船 is <kanji>ship</kanji>, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a <vocabulary>space ship</vocabulary>).

Remember how 履く is "to put on shoes" and 物 means "thing"? Well, combine them and you have a word for things you put on your feet, a.k.a. <vocabulary>footwear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoes</vocabulary>.

You might know that 履く is used for lots of different clothes you wear below the waist, but be careful: <vocabulary>履き物</vocabulary> only refers to footwear and shoes.
You know that 説得 is <kanji>persuasion</kanji>, so what is the verb version of that? <vocabulary>To persuade</vocabulary>.
If 混乱 is <kanji>confusion</kanji> then making it into a verb would cause it <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decrease</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decrease something</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The <reading>rush</reading> (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>continue</kanji>, so 続ける means <vocabulary>to continue something</vocabulary>. It's a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You can 続ける your work, for example, and you should 続ける your WaniKani lessons at a pace that works for you!

Although it has the same 続 kanji, this word is a bit different from 続く, which is used for when something just continues on its own (like rain, or trends). It can be hard to remember the difference, so here's a mnemonic to help you with 続ける:

You only <reading>care</reading> (ける) about things that you can continue through your own actions. For those other things that just continue on their own, you're like, That's <reading>coo</reading>' (く), but you’re not that interested.

A <kanji>noun</kanji> (名詞) that <kanji>has</kanji> <kanji>hard</kanji>ness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a <vocabulary>proper noun</vocabulary>.

Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb is done to some <kanji>other</kanji> thing, it's a <vocabulary>transitive verb</vocabulary>.

That means it takes a direct object. Verbs like 食べる, 使う, and 上げる are transitive verbs because they need a direct object, an "other" thing, to receive their action.

A <kanji>group</kanji> that has <kanji>power</kanji> using <kanji>violence</kanji>? Sounds like a <vocabulary>crime syndicate</vocabulary> to me, probably the <vocabulary>Yakuza</vocabulary> or some other <vocabulary>gangster organization</vocabulary> .
I have a <kanji>suspicion</kanji> (容疑) about <kanji>someone</kanji>. That someone is my main <vocabulary>suspect</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>tribe</kanji> that <kanji>runs wild</kanji> (暴走) is what the Japanese call a <vocabulary>biker gang</vocabulary>. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!

When a <kanji>passage of time</kanji> <kanji>comes to an end</kanji>, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all <vocabulary>economics</vocabulary>, baby (that's money, baby!).

You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you <kanji>add</kanji> and then <kanji>decrease</kanji> you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to <vocabulary>cut it out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cut the BS</vocabulary>!

Someone takes your <kanji>hand</kanji> and shows you how to <kanji>continue</kanji>. "This is the <vocabulary>procedure</vocabulary>," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

敵 means <vocabulary>enemy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>opponent</vocabulary>, whether in war, sports, competitions, or other conflict situations. Just keep in mind that 敵 can sound a bit strong!

Your <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>enemy</kanji> is your worst enemy. Your <vocabulary>arch enemy</vocabulary>.

大敵 is for a powerful or dangerous opponent, whether it's a <vocabulary>formidable adversary</vocabulary> in battle or competition, or something abstract, like calling carelessness your <vocabulary>great enemy</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>nothing</kanji> when it comes to <kanji>enemies</kanji>. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are <vocabulary>unrivaled</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>invincible</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>come to an end</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>committee</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is a <vocabulary>member of a committee</vocabulary> (or a <vocabulary>committee member</vocabulary>).

When you <kanji>raise</kanji> something you are causing it <vocabulary>to be raised</vocabulary>. This verb can also mean things like <vocabulary>to be listed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be nominated</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>. For these additional meanings, you might want to imagine something rising up onto a list or someone rising up to a nomination, because lists and nominations are always high up.
You have to <kanji>choose</kanji> someone and <kanji>raise</kanji> them up to office. This is an <vocabulary>election</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>child</kanji> of a <kanji>judge</kanji> is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
If you <kanji>control</kanji> people, you make them wear the same <kanji>clothes</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>uniform</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>control</kanji> every <kanji>degree</kanji> of this <vocabulary>system</vocabulary>. Think about a system. It's designed to create more control for you, degree by degree by degree. That's why they call it "The system," after all.

They have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> over us. This means they never stop <vocabulary>forcing</vocabulary> us into <vocabulary>compulsion</vocabulary>s or making all sorts of things <vocabulary>compulsory</vocabulary>.

強制 means making someone do something against their will, often through pressure, threats, or authority. It's used when someone is forced to sign a document under coercion, for example, or when someone is made to return to their country by force. 強制 means there's no choice in the matter.
<kanji>Self</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> is <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self restraint</vocabulary>. Have some!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>task</kanji> so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going <vocabulary>to work as</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to serve as</vocabulary> something to do that task.

When the <kanji>occurrence</kanji> of your <kanji>task</kanji>s is in the same <kanji>place</kanji> every day, that place is probably an <vocabulary>office</vocabulary>.

事務所 is often for office spaces that handle back-office 事務 (administrative or clerical work). It can also be used for offices that offer more specialized services, like a 会計事務所 (accounting <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>) or 芸能事務所 (talent <vocabulary>agency</vocabulary>).

My <kanji>righteousness</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is my <vocabulary>obligation</vocabulary> to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary>!
You have a <kanji>duty</kanji>. You have a <kanji>task</kanji>. You have both a <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary> and a <vocabulary>task</vocabulary> to do.
When you take the <kanji>whole</kanji> and <kanji>join</kanji> it together, you get a <vocabulary>synthesis</vocabulary>, and probably a good <vocabulary>overall</vocabulary> picture of things.
With the <kanji>whole</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji>. Do it <vocabulary>as a whole</vocabulary> instead of as a part, or something.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>establish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to set up</vocabulary>.

設ける is a formal word that suggests setting up something in order to prep for future needs or events. If you want to ensure smooth operation or governance, for example, you might set up rules (ルールを設ける) or establish an office (オフィスを設ける). You can even use it to say you’ll arrange a drinking party (酒の席を設ける), in which case it probably means the party has a more formal purpose like networking or discussion.

What do you <kanji>establish</kanji> and <kanji>determine</kanji> in your every day life? A setting. When you make that into a verb, you have the word <vocabulary>to set</vocabulary>, as in setting the temperature of the AC, setting your password, or setting your computer to dark mode.

設定する is a little formal, but does get commonly used for device, system, and game settings. It's also often used in more official contexts, like for setting prices for products or establishing project goals.
It's <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>establish</kanji>ment. It is <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.

You do the <kanji>build</kanji>ing to <kanji>establish</kanji> something. This whole process is called <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary>!

建設 is a pretty formal word for construction, focusing on the action or process of <vocabulary>constructing</vocabulary> rather than the structure itself. It’s often used for large construction projects, like malls, dams, or bridges. In some contexts, it can also refer to the <vocabulary>establishment</vocabulary> of significant entities, like a new state.
To start a business, your <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>resource</kanji> is your <vocabulary>capital</vocabulary>, which can be money and various other types of assets, like real estate properties.

The <kanji>resources</kanji> of <kanji>gold</kanji> that we have are our current <vocabulary>funds</vocabulary>. 

資金 is specifically for monetary funds, not other types of assets. That 金 kanji can mean money, so it should be easy to remember.

If you use <kanji>resources</kanji> to make <kanji>material</kanji>, you'll have <vocabulary>material</vocabulary>. This is in the sense of material for a book, or <vocabulary>data</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>documents</vocabulary> for research.
Go ahead and <kanji>throw</kanji> your <kanji>resources</kanji> at the project. It could use the <vocabulary>investment</vocabulary>.
<kanji>People</kanji> <kanji>Rights</kanji> are <vocabulary>human rights</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>rights</kanji> to <kanji>profit</kanji>! This is <vocabulary>a right</vocabulary> you have!

A <kanji>clause</kanji> in the <kanji>matter</kanji> complicates things. It adds <vocabulary>conditions</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>terms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>requirements</vocabulary> to an otherwise simple matter.

An <kanji>occurrence</kanji> of some <kanji>matter</kanji> is really just something that happens. It's an <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>case</vocabulary>. 

事件 often refers to significant or serious occurrences like crime cases or accidents. It can also be used playfully — "There was a 事件 at the party!" — to dramatize an event like someone asking out your classmate.

This is a weird one. Just think about the <kanji>sect</kanji> of <kanji>hand</kanji>s. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all <vocabulary>showy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>flashy</vocabulary>. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.

People are <kanji>stand</kanji>ing and forming a <kanji>sect</kanji> for you because of the <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> things you say and do. Your <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> conduct has brought them to their feet, and now they're worshipping you like some new age guru.

立派 is a slightly formal word used to say something or someone is <vocabulary>impressive</vocabulary>. For example, you might call someone who achieved something great a 立派な人, or describe an elegant, expensive-looking building as a 立派な建物. Even a fine, majestic mustache could be called a 立派なヒゲ!
Okayama (岡山) <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.

When you want to use the most basic <kanji>element</kanji>s of a <kanji>material</kanji>, you end up with <vocabulary>raw material</vocabulary>s. Maybe it's the raw materials you're going to use to build a house. Maybe it's the raw materials you need to make a good soup. Either way, they haven't been touched much (yet).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji>. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary> them whatever it is they want.
I <kanji>judge</kanji> to <kanji>cut off</kanji> your head. That is my <vocabulary>judgment</vocabulary>!
A <kanji>criticism</kanji> is when you <kanji>judge</kanji>. It is still just a <vocabulary>criticism</vocabulary>.
My <kanji>idea</kanji> of <kanji>duty</kanji> is that you don't really have to do it. It's <vocabulary>optional</vocabulary>, you know?
We're going to need to <kanji>examine</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> you for our annual <vocabulary>checkup</vocabulary>, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.

You <kanji>examine</kanji> the <kanji>problem</kanji>. In order to do this, you need <vocabulary>to inspect</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary> it. And if you're inspecting people like this, you're probably the police.
There are many <kanji>clause</kanji>s about the <kanji>promise</kanji>s you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a <vocabulary>treaty</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blame</kanji> so this also means <vocabulary>to blame</vocabulary>. Additionally, this can also mean <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to reproach</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to accuse</vocabulary>.
You can <kanji>blame</kanji> <kanji>duty</kanji> all you want, but you still have a <vocabulary>responsibility</vocabulary> as well, no matter what your duty dictates.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conserve</kanji>... but why stop there when you could try <vocabulary>to omit</vocabulary> everything and <vocabulary>to eliminate</vocabulary> everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else.

If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>conserve</kanji>, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reflection</vocabulary>, and see if that's really the right way to be. If you change your thinking, you might even end up showing <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>increase</kanji>, so the vocabulary verb version means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary>. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to <reading>err</reading> (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).

This is an everyday word that refers to an increase in number or quantity, but keep in mind that it cannot be used to express an increase in degree.

An <kanji>increase</kanji> will <kanji>add</kanji> to what you had before. This is an <vocabulary>increase</vocabulary>.

This word refers to an increase in number or quantity, often used in formal contexts, reports, or news articles.
A <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>increase</kanji> is just that, a <vocabulary>sudden increase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>surge</vocabulary>!
When you <kanji>increase</kanji> <kanji>tax</kanji> you're doing a <vocabulary>tax increase</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>tax</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> is what you have to pay when you have to pay a <vocabulary>tax</vocabulary>.
When the <kanji>tax</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> things are <vocabulary>tax free</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>truth</kanji> <kanji>occasion</kanji> is <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. This word is also used a lot as an adverb (with or without the particle に) to mean <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>really</vocabulary>.
You have an <kanji> occasion</kanji> to check out another <kanji>country</kanji>. Wow, so <vocabulary>international</vocabulary>!

Even though the kanji mainly means <kanji>occasion</kanji>, for some reason this word means <vocabulary>side</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary>. I suppose on <kanji>occasion</kanji> kanji takes you to the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recognize</kanji> or <kanji>acknowledge</kanji>, so the verb also means <vocabulary>to acknowledge</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perceive</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to admit</vocabulary>, among others.

This can be used to mean recognizing somebody or something visually, as well as in the sense of "to acknowledge" or "to admit". So you can use this verb to recognize someone's presence, achievements, marriage, or your own defeat. That said, you'll usually see 認める in the sense of "to acknowledge".

Just be sure to make <kanji>certain</kanji> that you <kanji>recognize</kanji> him. We need <vocabulary>confirmation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>verification</vocabulary>, so make certain again, please.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plan</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>correct</kanji> <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is always your <vocabulary>righteousness</vocabulary>. It is your form of <vocabulary>justice</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>main</kanji> cause behind someone's <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is usually what <vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>doctrine</vocabulary>s they believe in. Buddh<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, Shinto<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, social<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, commun<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, you name it. If you believe in one of those it's the main driving factor behind what you believe righteousness to be.

You have <kanji>righteousness</kanji> and then a <kanji>reason</kanji> behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your <vocabulary>sense of duty</vocabulary>. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.

This word can also mean <vocabulary>in-law</vocabulary> like your mother-in-law, because they're your mother in the social obligation sense only, not by blood.
Please <kanji>determine</kanji> what <kanji>righteousness</kanji> means. I want the <vocabulary>definition</vocabulary> for it.

What should you establish to <kanji>conserve</kanji> a country? The <vocabulary>Ministry of</vocabulary>… well, any ministry really. In Japanese, 〜省 often gets tacked on to the names of government ministries. Like the Ministry of Finance (財務省), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (外務省), and the mouthful that is the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (文部科学省). Whew!

〜省 is also the suffix used for Chinese <vocabulary>province</vocabulary>s, such as 広東省 (Guangdong Province), so keep this in mind when reading about international affairs.

Remember how the vocabulary word 身 can mean "animal flesh"? Well, when you <kanji>stab</kanji> some animal flesh and eat it raw, you're having <vocabulary>sashimi</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>sliced raw fish</vocabulary> (and sometimes other raw seafood).

Of course, you shouldn't actually stab your sashimi when you eat it — that would be rude. Just handle it with chopsticks and dip it in soy sauce and wasabi. Yum! And if you want to make a good impression, you can call it お刺身 to sound more polite — especially when ordering.
埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> something.

A 形容詞 is an <kanji>adjective</kanji>. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a <vocabulary>na adjective</vocabulary>. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say <reading>nah</reading>, I don't care about this anymore.

A <kanji>reality</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> is what you get when something feels real. The <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary> sets in — whatever this thing is, you've got a <vocabulary>real feeling</vocabulary> that it's actually happening.

実感 means a realization that comes from lived experience. For example, when you're expecting a baby, you may understand that you're becoming a parent, but not truly have that realization until the baby is born or you hold them in your arms. It's the sense of something feeling real beyond theory or explanation — when it truly sinks in.

Once you've <kanji>solve</kanji>d a <kanji>theory</kanji>, you should be able to give a pretty good <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> of it to somebody else. Makes sense, right? 

解説 refers to a detailed and analytical explanation. It's often used when someone, often an expert, provides an in-depth analysis about a topic, like a sports game or news article <vocabulary>commentary</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Cloth</kanji> from the <kanji>earth</kanji> is still <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary>, just a little dirty.

With time your <kanji>body</kanji> will <kanji>acquire</kanji> a certain type of <vocabulary>character</vocabulary>. It shows your true <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> as a person.

Note: We almost always use this word in the phrases 得体が知れない/得体の知れない, so check out the context sentences to see what kind of "character" we're talking about.

What does your <kanji>heart</kanji> want to <kanji>acquire</kanji> above all other things? <vocabulary>Knowledge</vocabulary>! That's why you're here, isn't it? 

Dig deep and see that all your heart wants is more <vocabulary>tips</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rules</vocabulary>, to gain a better <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> of… Japanese!

心得 refers to practical skills or knowledge gained through learning, like expertise in tea ceremony or mastery of a foreign language. It can also mean things to keep in mind in certain situations, like phone etiquette or know-how for a job.

If your <kanji>eye</kanji>s are <kanji>awake</kanji> then you're going <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary>. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know? 

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to awaken</vocabulary> but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.

The credible <kanji>resources</kanji> that determine your professional <kanji>status</kanji> are your <vocabulary>qualifications</vocabulary>. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>envy</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to envy</vocabulary> someone.
<kanji>Envy</kanji> consumes your <kanji>hope</kanji> turning it all to <vocabulary>envy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jealousy</vocabulary>.
Double <kanji>frustration</kanji> would cause anyone <vocabulary>to get irritated</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get annoyed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to grow impatient</vocabulary>.
You know that 飲酒 is "drinking alcohol" and 運転する is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means <vocabulary>drunk driving</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>drinking and driving</vocabulary>.

This word ends with a う sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means <kanji>nothing</kanji>, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to <vocabulary>to get rid of something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to do away with something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose something</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, so the action is happening to something. So maybe you're getting rid of debt, or discrimination, or stress... Whatever it is, there's a direct object with this verb!

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be Given Something From Someone

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>receive</kanji>, making this <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>, or alternatively, <vocabulary>to get something from someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be given something</vocabulary>.

You 立つ and then 去る. Makes sense, as in order <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>, you'll have to stand up first.

立ち去る describes the physical act of leaving a place, often used when walking away from a scene or departing a place after some kind of incident or event.
The kanji means <kanji>come true</kanji>, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, making this <vocabulary>to come true</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be fulfilled</vocabulary>.

Remember how 実る means "to bear fruit"? This is just the noun version of that word, so it means <vocabulary>harvest</vocabulary>. (A nice harvest is what you get when your crops literally bear fruit!)

Literally speaking, 実り refers to fruit and crops that are ripe and ready to be harvested. It's a bit old-fashioned and poetic, but you might see it in phrases like 実りの秋 (the fruitful season of autumn). Like the verb version 実る, it's more often used figuratively nowadays to refer to the <vocabulary>fruits</vocabulary> of hard work.
